abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Services and
            Institutional Development Project's outcome is assessed
            as satisfactory in supporting its private sector development
            objectives. Sustainability is likely for most activities.
            The project helped create an improved business environment
            in the agricultural sector, eliminated foot-and-mouth
            Disease and Citrus Canker, and supported Government's
            restructuring of the public sector. However, in the area of
            institutional strengthening, project financed activities
            were neither sustainable nor cost-effective. Key lessons
            learned include: a) thorough sector assessment permitted
            identification of key bottlenecks, addressed by public
            sector initiatives; b) organization of plant and animal
            health campaigns were the most effective
            government-sponsored activities to open new export markets;
            c) organized producer involvement from the outset permitted
            Government to pass-on operational responsibility to the
            private sector; d) in the absence of institutional capacity,
            project outputs were unable to effectively support
            development objectives; e) institutional strengthening
            activities should have been carried out directly with
            implementing agency staff, not project consultants, and
            required specific monitoring and evaluation indicators; and
            f) external implementation support should have been
            centralized in the project coordination unit, with
            assistance to implementing agencies provided within the
            context of their line operations under their direct responsibility.
